Within a single cloud phase, cloud cover and phase changes are not considered. Only cloud water path and cloud altitude remain as cloud drivers in these subsets. Still, the impact of increasing cloud opacity is pronounced. For each cloud phase type individually, the observed net flux change cannot be confidently explained without increasing cloud water path (+Non-cloud vs. Total in Fig. 3c–e). Further, net surface flux increases only during ice-only clouds because of their stronger change from thin to opaque clouds. The marked change under ice-only clouds highlights the importance of ice cloud processes for the overall surface radiative feedback during the cold winter at NSA.Our driver attribution methodology relies only on cloud and atmospheric observations (Section “Radiation driver attribution”). In other words, drivers are attributed independently from directly observed radiation. Yet the attributed total radiation change (+Cloud) is consistent with directly observed totals (Total) for all conditions. This agreement means that our method achieves radiative closure. In other words, our method correctly predicts the total radiation change from independently observed changes in cloud and atmospheric properties for all conditions.Changes independent of circulation variabilitySynoptic disturbances can drive transitions between clear and opaquely cloudy radiative states42. As such, short-term variations in the frequency of synoptic disturbances might confound the long-term cloud and radiation response to warming estimated above. For example, anomalously warm months may have more synoptic disturbances that would result in more opaque clouds. To control for this potential confounding, we leverage the established relationship between daily local surface pressure and radiative state in the wintertime western Arctic35,41,42,43 (Supplementary Fig. 5). By repeating key regressions stratifying by daily local surface pressure, circulation-induced transitions between clear and cloudy states are largely removed. We find that both net radiation and cloud water path increases are not due to local surface pressure variability.At all but extreme low pressures and weak high pressures, net surface flux increases with temperature (Fig. 4a). The magnitude of the increase is similar to the estimate without controlling for local surface pressure (Fig. 4b). In other words, net surface flux response to warming is generally independent of the circulation. As an additional line of evidence, there is a long-term warming trend but no local surface pressure trend 1998–2023 (Supplementary Fig. 4).Fig. 4: Circulation variability cannot explain increasing net surface flux and cloud water path.a, b Net surface flux and c, d cloud water path response to warming (Δ) with (a, c) and without (b, d) controlling for circulation variability. Circulation variability is removed by stratifying (binning) by daily local surface pressure anomaly. e Frequency of each local surface pressure anomaly bin. Bars show 95% confidence interval for regression slopes. c Total and individual ice and liquid contributions to cloud water path.Full size imageIn addition to net flux response, its key driver–cloud water path–increases independently from circulation variability (Fig. 4c). For all but extreme high pressures, cloud water path increases are similar to or greater than the initial unstratified estimate (Fig. 4d). Controlling for a different circulation confounder (reanalysis-derived temperature advection) yields the same result of robustly increasing net flux and cloud water path (Supplementary Fig. 6). Since controlling for synoptic disturbances by two independent methods did not remove or reverse our initial estimate of either cloud water path change or net flux change, we conclude that circulation variability does not confound our analysis. In other words, variations in atmospheric circulation cannot explain the relationship between temperature, cloud opacity, and net surface flux reported here.DiscussionThe main takeaway from this work is that, during winter, the surface of the North Slope of Alaska retains more energy with warming due to increasing cloud opacity. The local cloud feedback of 0.96 ± 0.64 W/m2/K cancels out the increased release of energy implied by the sum of all other (non-cloud) feedbacks. The total local radiative feedback at the surface is then positive. In other words, increasing surface temperatures do not increase surface radiative cooling because of changing cloud properties. This fact provides direct observational evidence that clouds contribute to surface-amplified warming during winter at NSA.Increasing cloud water path was the largest driver of the cloud feedback (0.57 ± 0.26 W/m2/K). Cloud water path increased in all cloud phase types, but ice-only cloud radiative effect increased more strongly because of its lower mean-state opacity. Increasing opacity of ice-only clouds drove the majority (77%) of the radiation increase from changing cloud water path. Dependence of the feedback on mean-state opacity suggests that constraining present-day cloud water path in thin ice clouds may be key to constraining the wintertime Arctic cloud feedback.While an ice-to-liquid cloud transition occurred, it was not the largest cloud feedback driver. Cloud-phase change increased surface radiation by 0.29 ± 0.54 W/m2/K, while the thin-to-opaque ice cloud transition increased surface radiation by 0.44 ± 0.06 W/m2/K. The secondary role of cloud-phase change at NSA highlights the importance of ice processes during the cold winter. Even though conversion of ice to liquid has a clear physical explanation and has received much attention, it may have a smaller effect than increasing ice production during winter. Future work might develop along two lines of inquiry – what cloud processes drive increased ice production and increasing cloud opacity generally? Does a thin-to-opaque cloud transition occur in other seasons and regions of the Arctic, or is it unique to NSA winter?MethodsDataThe ARM NSA facility is one of the most heavily instrumented ground-based observatories in the world33. Among the many measurements available, two datasets form the core of this study: surface longwave radiation (QCRAD54) and comprehensive cloud properties (Shupe-Turner microphysics55).The first portion of this study (Section “Observed changes in surface radiative fluxes”) relies only on QCRAD and surface meteorology56,57. The lengthy (1998–2023) and well-calibrated record captures how the radiation is responding to warming. In order to explain the response, however, more observations are needed.In the second portion of this study (Section “Drivers of increasing downward radiation”), cloud and atmospheric observations are introduced to explain the changing radiation. Cloud observations come from a multi-sensor retrieval suite developed specifically for use in the Arctic –Shupe-Turner microphysics55. With 13 years of observations combining many instruments (radar, lidar, ceilometer, microwave radiometer, radiosonde), it offers the detail typically associated with a field campaign at the duration more typical of a satellite mission. Combined with temperature and humidity from radiosondes58, it offers everything needed to explain the radiation.Radiative transferCloud and atmospheric observations can be supplied to a radiative transfer model to enable a powerful tool to explain changes in the actual observed radiation. We use the Rapid Radiative Transfer Model–Longwave (RRTM-LW)59 to calculate radiation from observed cloud and atmospheric state, as described in55. Calculations are done by supplying Shupe-Turner cloud microphysics and temperature/humidity profiles58,60,61 to RRTM-LW. Since cloud and atmospheric state are observed independently from surface radiation, comparison provides a natural opportunity for validation.By comparing calculated to observed radiation, we can check our ability to explain the radiation. Such a check is important because several instrument upgrades (radar and lidar) may affect the long-term explanatory power of observations. We compare a 20-minute rolling average of calculated radiation to observed radiation during the minute in the center of the averaging window55.Validation quality is stable over time, with consistent performance in every year (Fig. 5a). The median difference is near or less than that expected from radiometric observational uncertainty for every year (±5 W/m2 for minute-frequency observations). The all-time median difference is −2.6 W/m2, while the smallest (largest) is 0.1 (−6.1) W/m2 in 2018 (2005). The interquartile range of differences is also generally near this expected  ±5 W/m2 spread. The all-time average interquartile range is 13.1 W/m2, while the minimum (maximum) is 9.2 (18.8) W/m2 in 2014 (2006). For each year (Supplementary Table 1), our degree of closure is similar to existing state-of-the-art Arctic closure exercises (Supplementary Table 2)24,55,62,63,64. Consistent performance over time shows that the data are suitable for long-term analysis.Fig. 5: Evaluation of cloud and atmospheric measurements.Agreement between directly observed and calculated fluxes from cloud and atmospheric observations a over time and b over the entire data record. Bars in (a) show median and interquartile range of differences for DJFM. Shaded area indicates instantaneous measurement uncertainty of radiometers of  ±5 W/m2. Regression of calculated against observed radiation (dotted line) (b) and one-to-one line (dashed line).Full size imageIn addition to long-term stability, instantaneous variations in radiative flux are well-explained by cloud and atmospheric observations. Cloud and atmospheric observations explain 87% of the minute-frequency variance in observed radiation (Fig. 5b). Calculated and observed fluxes are evenly distributed along the 1:1 line from the coldest to warmest conditions. Good performance over all conditions suggests that cloud observations (and calculations) are suitable for explaining long-term changes in the surface downward longwave flux.Radiation distribution shape change attributionSurface radiation responds to warming, as do cloud and atmospheric properties. To link these two, we perturb observed cloud and atmospheric properties and recalculate radiative flux in RRTM-LW. First, we assess whether increasing temperatures and water vapor alone can explain the change over time in the net surface flux distribution.Surface longwave fluxes are recalculated with 4 degrees Kelvin added to surface and atmospheric temperatures for the entire data record. Water vapor increases with constant relative humidity. We find the change in the distribution of calculated net flux according to$$\Delta {n}_{k}^{calc}={n}_{k}({F}_{calc}(\,{\mbox{+4K}}))-{n}_{k}({F}_{calc}({{2004-2019}})),$$
                    (1)
                where nk(Fcalc(X)) indicates the relative frequency of bin k in the histogram of calculated net surface flux Fcalc under a condition X. Expected change in net flux distribution \(\Delta {n}_{k}^{calc}\) is then added to the directly observed (not calculated) net surface flux distribution nk(Fobs). Then \(\Delta {n}_{k}^{calc}\) is added to the net flux distribution from the first decade of observations according to$${n}_{k}({F}_{obs}(\,{{\mbox{+4K}}}))=\Delta {n}_{k}^{calc}+{n}_{k}({F}_{obs}({{{1998-2009}}})),$$
                    (2)
                where nk(Fcalc(X)) refers to the observed net surface flux histogram for a condition X. This perturbed distribution nk(Fobs(+4K)) is then plotted in Fig. 1c and labeled as warming and water vapor alone (+4K). By comparing the expected change in the 1998–2008 distribution to the actual 2013–2023 distribution, it can be assessed whether warming and water vapor alone could be responsible for the net surface flux change over time.Radiation driver attributionTo further understand why surface longwave fluxes are changing, we find the radiation change due to changes in each cloud and atmospheric property individually. This approach allows us, for example, to isolate the effects of changing cloud properties on the radiation. We call these radiatively important cloud and atmospheric properties drivers. We quantify 8 drivers – 4 non-cloud (Planck, lapse-rate, CO2, water vapor) and 4 cloud drivers (cloud water path, cloud phase, cloud cover, cloud base height) – which explain the total surface downward longwave radiation change.Driver effects are attributed through a first-order Taylor series approximation. For each driver xi, its contribution to flux change with warming (dF/dT) is$${\left.\frac{dF}{dT}\right| }_{{x}_{i}}\approx \frac{\partial F}{\partial {x}_{i}}\frac{\partial {x}_{i}}{\partial T}.$$
                    (3)
                The first term (∂F/∂xi) is the radiative effect of a change in driver xi, and the second term (∂xi/∂T) is the change in driver xi with warming. The first term ∂F/∂xi is found by perturbing a single driver xi in observed cloud and atmospheric profiles and calculating the radiative effect of the perturbation (i.e., sensitivity) with RRTM-LW. Profiles are taken from radiosonde launches and microphysics averaged in a 31-minute window centered on sonde launch time. The second term ∂xi/∂T is found via ordinary least squares regression of monthly-mean anomalies in xi against monthly-mean anomalies in near-surface air temperature T.Decomposition by cloud phaseThe radiative effect of changes in drivers depends on mean cloud and atmospheric state. For example, opaque clouds would be insensitive to liquid water path changes while thin clouds would be highly sensitive. Since cloud phase is a primary control on opacity, we calculate (3) separately for each cloud phase type. Driver attribution is then split into four states with distinct radiative responses to perturbations - clear skies, ice-only clouds, mixed-phase clouds, and liquid-only clouds.We classify each observation into one of these four categories by aggregating the vertically-resolved hydrometeor phase classification in the Shupe-Turner product. Classification is simple for ice-only, since it is defined to be no liquid anywhere in the profile. Classification is less straightforward for liquid-only, since high ice clouds often overlie liquid-containing layers. A profile is classified as liquid-only if a cloud contains a liquid-only volume without ice at the boundaries of the liquid-containing cloud layer. If liquid and ice are present in the same cloud, it is classified to mixed-phase whether or not the liquid and ice co-occur at the same vertical level. These three cloud phase type definitions are mutually exclusive, so each cloudy profile is classified into only one category.With observations separated into these four categories, we can decompose (3) by cloud phase type. The all-sky effect of changes in xi is a weighted mean of its effects in each state j:$${\left.\frac{dF}{dT}=\frac{dF}{dT}\right| }_{{x}_{i}}+{\left.\frac{dF}{dT}\right| }_{{f}_{j}}\approx {\sum}_{i,j}{f}_{j}\frac{\partial {F}_{j}}{\partial {x}_{ij}}\frac{\partial {x}_{ij}}{\partial T}+{\sum}_{j}\frac{\partial F}{\partial {f}_{j}}\frac{\partial {f}_{j}}{\partial T},$$
                    (4)
                where fj is the overall frequency of state j. Changes in the frequency of each state j are added as drivers. Driving by changes in state frequencies fj (\(dF/dT{| }_{{f}_{j}}\)) is a product of two terms. The first term ∂F/∂fj is calculated by resampling (bootstrapping) the observed distribution of radiation to have a more-frequent state j. This resampling gives the effect of a change in fj on all-sky average F. The second term ∂fj/∂T is found by regressing monthly-mean anomalies in fj against monthly-mean anomalies in T.Most drivers can be calculated from (4). Drivers evaluated from (4) are vertically constant warming (Planck driver), vertically constant warming minus observed vertical structure of warming (lapse rate driver), observed vertical structure of atmospheric moistening (water vapor driver), vertically constant CO2 mixing ratio increase (direct CO2 driver), cloud altitude decrease with constant cloud base potential temperature (cloud base height driver), and change overall cloud cover without a change in cloud phase (cloud cover). Increasing cloud cover is diagnosed from the effect of decreasing fclr.Uncertainty analysisWe report 95% confidence intervals for attributed dF/dT. These are calculated by propagating uncertainty from partial derivatives in Eq. (4). The two categories of terms are driver response to warming (∂xi/∂T and ∂fj/∂T) and flux sensitivity to driver (∂F/∂xi and ∂F/∂fj). For uncertainty in the driver response to warming, we use 95% confidence intervals on regression slopes evaluated using Student’s t-distribution (note that all regression uncertainty in this study is evaluated this manner). For uncertainty in the flux sensitivity to driver, we use the 5th and 95th percentiles from the population of observed sensitivities. To convert 95% confidence intervals to scalar uncertainties, we assume \(\delta=\frac{{F}_{{{{\rm{cdf}}}}}(0.95)-{F}_{{{{\rm{cdf}}}}}(0.05)}{2}\), where Fcdf is a cumulative distribution function of an uncertain term and δ is the uncertainty in that term. Note that uncertainty in dF/dT for Planck and Lapse rate drivers comes only from ∂F/∂xi because temperature is the driver xi (∂xi/∂T = 1).Cloud phase change attributionTo separate cloud cover changes from cloud phase changes, we define the relative frequency of cloud phase types rj as$${r}_{j}=\frac{{f}_{j}}{1-{f}_{clr}},\ j\,\ne \,clr.$$
                    (5)
                The cloud phase driver is the radiative effect of changes in the frequency of each cloud phase type relative to all clouds. This effect is calculated from$${\left.\frac{dF}{dT}\right| }_{{{{\rm{phase}}}}}=(1-{f}_{clr}){\sum}_{\ j\ne clr}\frac{\partial {F}_{cld}}{\partial {r}_{j}}\frac{\partial {r}_{j}}{\partial T}.$$
                    (6)
                We calculate ∂Fcld/∂rj by bootstrapping cloudy-sky radiation to have a more-frequent state rj. We calculate ∂rj/∂T by regressing monthly-mean anomalies in rj against monthly-mean anomalies in T. Uncertainty is calculated for (6) as in Section “Uncertainty analysis”.Cloud water path change attributionTo diagnose the effect of increasing ice and liquid water paths, we use the binned approach of65. Liquid and ice water path is resolved into a histogram nj(Wk). Driving by each water path bin Wk in each cloud phase j is calculated separately according to$${\left.\frac{\partial F}{\partial T}\right| }_{W}={\sum}_{j,k}{f}_{j}CR{E}_{j}({W}_{k})\frac{\partial {n}_{j}({W}_{k})}{\partial T},$$
                    (7)
                where W is ice or liquid water path, Wk is the water path bin, and CREj(Wk) is the average observed cloud radiative effect for phase j and water path bin Wk. Cloud radiative effect is diagnosed from observations by setting cloud fraction to zero and recalculating radiation with RRTM-LW. The term ∂nj(Wk)/∂T is evaluated by regressing monthly-mean anomalies in the frequency of each water path bin nj(Wk) against monthly-mean anomalies in T. The cloud water path driver is the sum of the effects of increasing ice and liquid water paths. Uncertainty is calculated from (7) as in Section “Uncertainty analysis”. By evaluating Eqs. (4), (6), and (7), we find the downward surface longwave radiation increase attributable to 8 drivers separated by cloud phase.

items.title: Tra mare e terra nasce “Sud Adriatico”
items.description:
Il nuovo progetto per il ripristino del paesaggio marino e costiero della Puglia meridionale 
The post Tra mare e terra nasce “Sud Adriatico&#82
items.body: In evidenza Il Panda Siamo Noi In evidenza Il leopardo delle Nevi In evidenza Adotta una specie Per il ripristino del paesaggio marino e costiero della Puglia meridionale Difesa dall’erosione costiera causata dalle mareggiate, maggiore sicurezza contro gli effetti della crisi climatica, recupero delle popolazioni ittiche di interesse commerciale, assorbimento del carbonio, produzione di ossigeno. Questi sono solo alcuni degli effetti, i cosiddetti servizi ecosistemici, gratuitamente garantiti da un paesaggio marino e costiero in buona salute in cui dune sabbiose e fondali di posidonia e coralligeno sono integri e vitali. Comunità coinvolte per assicurare entro il 2030 una rete ecologicamente connessa ed efficacemente gestita di habitat protetti Per assicurare alla comunità questi servizi ha preso il via il progetto “Sud Adriatico-ripristino del paesaggio marino e costiero della Puglia meridionale” con il kick-off meeting del 28-29 ottobre al Palazzo Granafei-Nervegna di Brindisi. Il kick-off meeting del 28-29 ottobre al Palazzo Granafei-Nervegna di Brindisi Tra i partner il WWF Italia e il WWF Mediterraneo (leader di progetto), il Parco Naturale Regionale delle Dune Costiere, il Consorzio di Gestione di Torre Guaceto, il Comune di Lecce con il Parco Naturale Regionale Bosco Paludi di Rauccio, la Riserva Naturale Statale de Le Cesine/Oasi WWF e il Comune di Vernole, la Stazione Zoologica Anton Dohrn, il DISTAV (Dipartimento di Scienze della Terra, dell’Ambiente e della Vita) dell’Università di Genova, e la Regione Puglia/Assessorato all’Ambiente. Per i prossimi 5 anni i partner saranno impegnati nelrivitalizzare, in un’estensione di circa 52.000 ettari, almeno 1.000 ettari di habitat prioritari marino-costieri, capitalizzando su interventi passati e sulle buone pratiche del territorio per creare una rete di protezione efficace ecologicamente connessa e ricucire gli ‘strappi’ prodotti dal degrado e dagli impatti umani. Le azioni per proteggere la Posidonia Le azioni del progetto prevedono interventi di ripristino e protezione di Posidonia, coralligeno e dune costiere e la gestione sostenibile delle attività a mare. Chiave sarà il forte coinvolgimento della comunità locale che diventerà custode del territorio: tutti gli attori, università e istituzioni locali verranno coinvolti durante l’intera durata del progetto per instaurare una gestione partecipativa del territorio che garantisca benefici socio-economici, anche in termini di adattamento e mitigazione climatica. Si contribuirà così alla Strategia per la Biodiversità e alla Legge sul Ripristino della Natura (Nature Restoration Law) dell’Unione Europea, uno strumento fondamentale entrato in vigore nel 2024 che punta a rivitalizzare almeno il 20% degli ecosistemi marini degradati entro il 2030. Tra questi le praterie di fanerogame marine, come Posidonia oceanica, sono tra gli habitat più colpiti: considerata il polmone del Mare Nostrum, la Posidonia ha perso negli ultimi 50 anni quasi il 35% della sua estensione. Un ‘alleato’ che in questi ultimi decenni abbiamo trattato molto male: queste piante, infatti, producono fino a 20 litri di ossigeno al giorno per ogni metro quadrato e immagazzinano carbonio 35 volte più velocemente di una foresta tropicale, anche per lunghi periodi, persino secoli o millenni e in maniera estremamente efficiente. La loro presenza, inoltre, garantisce la protezione delle coste riducendo del 20% l’energia delle onde e ospita oltre 50 specie ittiche di interesse commerciale. Il progetto fa parte del programma internazionale ELSP – Endangered Landscape & Seascape Programme finanziato dalla fondazione Arcadia.

Synergistic analysis of climate and anthropogenic impacts on NPP dynamics in India’s Western Ghats using geodetector
                    Sanjay Kumar1 nAff2, Jyothika Karkala1, Joyal Arya1 & …Rajiv Kumar Chaturvedi1 Show authors

Scientific Reports

volume 15, Article number: 38252 (2025)
            Cite this article
                    
                    
        
        
            
                
                    
                        276 Accesses
                    
                
                
                
                    
                        
                            1 Altmetric
                        
                    
                
                
                    
                        Metrics details

Subjects
        
            Climate-change ecologyClimate-change impactsEnvironmental health

AbstractThe importance of integrating climate resilience into conservation efforts to safeguard the Western Ghats, one of the hottest hotspots in the world, is underscored by our findings. The research was designed to provide an integrated approach to help preserve the ecological productivity in a biodiversity sensitive area. The study investigates the dynamics of terrestrial productivity, examining its trends over time (2001–2023) and identifying the various factors that influence it, a topic that has been understudied in this biodiversity hotspot. In 2019, Net Primary Productivity (NPP) results experienced significant declines across all land cover types, with the decline starting in 2015 when forest NPP dropped by 0.24 and cropland by 0.1 kg C m\(^{-2}\) year\(^{-1}\). The NPP steadily recovered the following year, especially in the croplands. The factor detector q value indicated the degree of influence of each factor as vegetation parameters (\(58.96\%\)), climatic indicators (\(21.97\%\)), anthropogenic factor (\(17.39\%\)), and topographic condition (\(1.68\%\)). Results from the innovative approach to assess spatial heterogeneity emphasize the influence of the combinations of Land Use Land Cover (LULC) with Fraction of Photosynthetically Active Radiation (FPAR), Leaf Area Index (LAI), Normalized Difference Vegetation Index (NDVI), Land Surface Temperature (LST), and Enhanced Vegetation Index (EVI), followed by LST interacting with FPAR, and NDVI with LAI, had the greatest impact on NPP. The study employs multiple regression to evaluate the effects of variables, the Mann–Kendall method for trend analysis, and Geo-detector for spatial variation.

IntroductionThe role of forests in regulating climate, transfer of energy, water balance, and carbon cycle by exchanging huge quantities of carbon with the atmosphere is indispensable in the terrestrial ecosystem1,2. Roughly 31% of the land area on Earth is made up of forests3 with the ability to absorb higher amounts of carbon in comparison to all the other ecosystems combined while providing ecosystem services worth trillions of dollars. Forests not only provide a spectrum of benefits but also possess the power to withstand and mitigate climate change4. The sustenance of the forest ecosystem is defined by the primary productivity. The rate at which autotrophic organisms along with plants convert solar energy into organic compounds through the process of photosynthesis in an ecosystem is the Gross Primary Productivity(GPP). The NPP is the GPP minus the rate at which some of these compounds are used through cellular respiration5. Globally, the GPP between the atmosphere and land makes up for the largest carbon flux about 130 Gt C year\(^{-1}\) as photosynthesis fixes the carbon determining the potential for carbon absorption2. NPP serves as a popularly utilized pivotal marker for the assessment of ecological security and as a measure of vegetation dynamics1.Climate change is contributing to the unfortunate decline in the productivity of forests6. Climate change marked by changing temperature (TEMP), and precipitation (PPT) conditions accompanied by a rise in \(CO_2\) affects a spectrum of forest services7. The continued human activity has been contributing to the rise of long-lived greenhouse gases and the build-up of these gases is likely to increase the surface air temperature by 1.5–4.5 °C in this century. Global NPP of the terrestrial ecosystem is bound to be affected by a change in climate of such a magnitude8. A key contributor to the negative feedback on climate warming is the enhanced vegetation productivity driven by the increasing concentration of carbon dioxide(\(CO_2\)) although there is a lack of clarity in the temporal dynamics of the process9. Lately, a climate-driven substantial change in forest ecosystems, characterized by an increase in the frequency and severity of disturbance regimes, has significantly impacted the productivity of ecosystem services. There is a high probability that the climate-induced disturbances could overshadow the ecological resilience of forests which possibly could perpetually shift the ecosystem balance10. A noteworthy number of interdependent climate factors fuel a series of short-term or permanent complications and ill effects on natural and human systems are the climate extremes such as drought, heavy precipitation, and heatwaves which can co-occur across the globe11,12,13,14,15,16,17,18. Apart from posing a threat to society, the concurrent extreme climate events are a danger to the forest ecosystem as hot and dry weather inhibits the capacity to suppress and can kick start wildfires causing extensive environmental impacts, forest mortality, and fire damages11. Another facet of forest stress comes from urban land expansion, as the impervious surface takes over the natural vegetation on the city-to-country scale, studies have indicated a reduction in the terrestrial NPP19.The current scenario of forest productivity has driven the conceptualization and application of multiple techniques to assess it. Among the land cover types, forests prove to be the most productive which has an average GPP of 2.0 kg C m\(^{-2}\) year\(^{-1}\) while cropland and grassland are estimated to be 1.8 and 1.5 kg C m\(^{-2}\) year\(^{-1}\) respectively2. Global biosphere productivity represents the most significant absorption flux of atmospheric carbon dioxide (\(CO_2\)) and is crucial for understanding both historical and future carbon cycles20. The temporal and spatial components of the NPP in the source region of the Yangtze River in China were carried out using data from the Carnegie-Ames-Stanford Approach model. The impact of climatic factors was studied and the result highlighted the key factors as temperature and precipitation on an inter-annual time scale and human activities in the downstream region1. Net ecosystem productivity (NEP) is fundamental to the forest carbon sink, and comparing NEP between natural and planted forests can aid in reaching carbon neutrality. As a result of soil fertilizer and higher stand age, the NEP in natural forests was lower than in planted ones. At the same time, as the mean annual air temperature decreased due to latitudinal variations, the GPP dropped in both the planted and natural forests21. The impact of meteorological and biophysical parameters on the NPP in the tropical deciduous forest of India showed that a decrease in NPP was attributed to rise in temperature combined with vapour pressure deficit22. The significant effect of precipitation on the NPP was revealed when studying the NPP in the forest plantation in India. Also, the modeled data tends to underestimate the value in comparison to the field-estimated data23. A study in India demonstrated that an 18.51% increase in LAI from 2001 to 2019 did not result in increased carbon uptake caused by warming constraints. It also revealed that in forests which are temporally consistent, a 6.19% decrease in NPP occurred despite a 6.75% increase in LAI24. The use of remote sensing, Residual Trend analysis, and correlation analysis showed that precipitation is the primary driver of NPP over 72% of the area in India. At the same time, temperature and solar radiation influenced NPP in the Himalayas and forested regions, respectively with a slight decline caused by human activities25. The geographic detector model (GDM) is utilized to understand the relative contribution of multiple climatic factors on vegetation activities while detecting the heterogeneity in spatial stratification26,27,28.Globally, 420 million hectares of forest land have vanished since 1990 from the conversion to anthropogenic uses. During the period 2015–2020, 10 million hectares of forest were cut down every year which is less than in the 1900s, when 16 million hectares per year were lost3. To safeguard and elevate the forest carbon sinks, multiple efforts for policy development and economic incentives are introduced such as the advancement in the carbon offset projects for forests on the global scale, and the Bonn Challenge for the restoration of landscape4. India is determined to expand its tree and forest cover creating an add-on of nearly 3 billion tonnes of carbon sink by the year 203029. Western Ghats, well known for its distinctive ecological and biophysical processes, is one of the ancient mountains. It stands at eighth position on the list of the world’s hottest hotspots due to its biodiversity. Unfortunately, the high-altitude montane forest ecosystem that controls the weather pattern of the monsoon in India is under threat due to the stress on habitat and climate change. Sustainable Development Goal (SDG) 15 “Life on land” of the United Nations (UN) encourages the promotion, restoration, and protection of the land. Achieving the SDG will be harmed if the downward trend in ecosystem and biodiversity persists3. The changing natural vegetation as a direct result of climate change modifies vegetation productivity. Reversing the fragmentation of forests is more of an impossible task with a focus on biodiversity loss along with encroachment activity and increased population pressure on the forest edges3. There is a lack of clarity when decoding the underlying mechanism and bringing remote sensing into play renders a resourceful and convenient channel for estimating NPP. Although being a sensitive zone, accompanied with growing anthropogenic activities, not enough research has been carried out in this region to understand the climate change dynamics. The study aims to understand the spatiotemporal aspect of the trend in NPP in the Western Ghats from 2001 to 2023. The GDM provides a multi dimensional look at the relationship between the various explanatory variables and NPP. It is useful in not only determining the magnitude but also the potential to independently influence the target variable. The influence of climatic parameters, vegetation indices, topography, and anthropogenic activities forms the focus of the research.ResultsThe combined impact of variables can be categorized as vegetation parameters (EVI, NDVI, LAI, FPAR), climate indicators (Precipitation, Temperature, LST), anthropogenic factors (LULC), and topographic condition (slope) in this section. The q value is a measure of the magnitude of the driving force determined by the factor detector. The range of the q value is from 0 to 1. It signifies the 100 x q% of how the independent variable can explain the change in NPP. The statistical significance is denoted by the p value. Precipitation also indirectly decides the magnitude of NDVI, EVI, LAI, and FPAR through edaphic factors. The consequent delayed impact on vegetation health due to reduced precipitation is because it takes time to influence soil moisture followed by vegetation indices. Optimal temperature is necessary for balanced NPP as either extremes in temperature will cause stress, reducing NPP. LST can directly influence the plant temperature along with the soil moisture. An increased plant respiration and evapotranspiration leading to duress in vegetation is seen in higher LST which is more apparent during periods of reduced PPT. NDVI and EVI which are fed by precipitation are measures of density and health of vegetation and rise with NPP. The drought study in India31,32, observed that there was a monsoon drought during the year 2002, which was also reflected in the NPP in the area in the subsequent year. The temperature displayed a varying effect depending on the year. The influence of predictors like temperature and precipitation on NPP is not uniform across years. This variability can be attributed to different environmental conditions, such as soil moisture, nutrient availability, and interaction with other climate factors. The consistently negative EVI coefficients suggest a complex dynamic where densely vegetated areas might not always translate to higher productivity. The power of the anthropogenic factor proved to be the highest followed by vegetation parameters driven by climatic conditions and barely any by the topographic indicator. The results from the interaction detector indicate that the interplay of precipitation, temperature, LULC, and vegetation indices significantly amplify NPP, highlighting the critical role of these variables in driving ecological productivity. The reduction in cropland area reflects ongoing changes in land use patterns within the Western Ghats, necessitating sustainable land management practices to maintain and potentially enhance cropland productivity amidst environmental and anthropogenic pressures. Although the average NPP of the Western Ghats saw a large drop in 2019, the ecological resilience helped the NPP to bounce back to the normal level by 2020. The NPP is decreasing in the forests even though the forests are increasing which may be attributed to the introduction of newer and younger forests. Apart from the chosen parameters, NPP is also influenced by soil moisture, \(CO_2\) level, humidity, dew point temperature, soil type and quality, wind, ecosystem type, and more. Future studies including all these parameters will provide more insights into the dynamics of NPP. In conclusion, the Western Ghats’ productivity is shaped by a combination of climatic variables, land use changes, and vegetation health. Effective management and conservation strategies are essential to mitigate the negative impacts and enhance the positive effects of these factors on NPP. The findings underscore the need for a holistic approach to preserve the biodiversity hotspot and sustain its ecological productivity. From a policy perspective, the results indicate a need to build a strong local governance through community based conservation efforts, and effective landscape level zoning. To sustain the forest productivity, as strict and locally driven conservation practices should be implemented to monitor the changing land use pattern. Integrating sustainable practices with stronger policy enforcement will be key to preserving the resilience of this critical biodiversity hotspot. The research underscores the urgency of integrating climate resilience into conservation strategies for the Western Ghats, renowned for its biodiversity and ecological importance, in response to significant climate threats.MethodsStudy areaThe Western Ghats boasts of being a landscape with rich ecological diversity sustaining all the forest classifications from grasslands to tropical wet evergreen forests, flowering plants having about 4000 different species, and ample fauna34. The forest types in the Western Ghats characterized as non-equatorial tropical evergreen forests have four major phenological attributes. The majority of the area is occupied by moist deciduous forests succeeded by semi-evergreen forests which have a greater level of vegetation diversity, evergreen forests with maximum level of endemism, and lastly, the dry deciduous forests prevalent on the leeward side of the mountain34. The Western Ghats sees a shift in climate with proximity to the equator as the latitude changes from 8\(^\circ\) 07’ 58” N to 21\(^\circ\) 15’ 58” N and the longitude from 72\(^\circ\) 53’ 31” E to 78\(^\circ\) 03’ 45” E (Fig. 10). The area expands from the coastline to a height of 2619 m above the mean sea level witnessing a range of topographic and climatic conditions. Stretching to a length of approximately 1500 Km, the study area stretches for 107,770 sq km from the southern tip of India, the Kanyakumari in Kerala to south of Gujarat including the Maharashtra, Goa, Karnataka, and Tamilnadu states35. The annual average precipitation is about 190 cm whereas the mean maximum and minimum precipitation is about 590 cm and 40 cm respectively. The minimum and maximum temperature in the region average 15 \(^\circ\)C and 30 \(^\circ\)C respectively while the annual average is around 26 \(^\circ\)C. This mountain range surfaced as a significant uplift along a rift shoulder during the Deccan Trap volcanic activity at the boundary between the Late Cretaceous and Paleocene epochs36. The calculation of EVI involves the soil-adjustment factor, coefficients of variation adjustments, and canopy background adjustments44.Land surface temperature (LST)The MODIS LST product (MOD11A2.061) which is a 8 day 1 Km resolution data is derived using the generalized split-window algorithm. Based on the land cover types, and atmospheric column water vapour, lower boundary air surface temperature, the 31 and 32 bands are estimated for the emissivities. Manageable sub-ranges of temperatures are calculated for efficient retrieval45.LAI and FPARThe LAI and FPAR products from MODIS (MOD15A2H.061) are developed from surface reflectances using the vegetation canopy radiative transfer algorithm46. This was put into implementation before the launch of MODIS on the TERRA platform.Digital elevation model (DEM)A globally continuous DEM with 30 m spatial resolution depends on applying radar interferometry algorithms to the Shuttle Radar Topography Mission (SRTM) data, which is then processed into a locally spherical coordinate system47.Experimental frameworkTrend analysisThe Mann Kendall (MK) test48,49 is applied to analyze the trend of the time series NPP data from 2001 to 2023. The nonparametric test checks for an increasing or a decreasing trend, along with the significance and monotonicity of the statistics. The trend may or may not be linear. The MK test holds an advantage over the regression analysis which requires the residual data to be normally distributed. The trend present is quantified by testing if the time series falls within the confidence interval which is given by the null hypothesis and the significance level50.$$\begin{aligned} S=\sum _{k=1}^{j-1} \sum _{l=k+1}^{j} sgn(a_l-a_k) \end{aligned}$$
                    (4)
                where the length of the NPP data is represented as j, while \(a_l\) and \(a_k\) are the sequential data values.$$\begin{aligned} sgn(a_l-a_k) = {\left\{ \begin{array}{ll} 1, if(a_l-a_k) >0\\ 0, if(a_l-a_k) =0\\ -1, if(a_l-a_k)<0 \end{array}\right. } \end{aligned}$$
                    (5)
                The mean is given as E(S) and variance as Var(S), with the random distribution of the variable, the normal distribution is approximated when \(j\ge 8\).$$\begin{aligned} & E(S)=0 \end{aligned}$$
                    (6)
                $$\begin{aligned} & \quad Var(S) = \frac{j(j-1)(2j+5)-\sum _{k=1}^{m}d_k(d_k-1)(2d_k+5)}{18} \end{aligned}$$
                    (7)
                where for the extent k, \(d_k\) is the number of ties and m is the number of tie groups. \(Z_S\) denotes the test statistics.$$\begin{aligned} Z_S = {\left\{ \begin{array}{ll} \frac{S-1}{\sqrt{Var(S)}}, if S>0\\ 0, if S=0\\ \frac{S+1}{\sqrt{Var(S)}}, if S<0\\ \end{array}\right. } \end{aligned}$$
                    (8)
                The result of the test reveals an increasing and decreasing trend with a positive and negative \(Z_S\) respectively. A test uses a confidence level of \(95\%\) with an \(\alpha\) value of 0.05.GDMSpatial heterogeneity is a fundamental characteristic of geographic phenomena. The models are statistically designed to detect spatially stratified heterogeneity and uncover the underlying driving forces27. The analysis of the spatial variability is covered by the GDM using the four geographical detectors. It is used to assess the influence of climatic and meteorological parameters on the productivity of the forest through geographical strata. The areas of risk are identified by the risk detector, and the factor responsible for it is recognized by the factor detector. The relative prominence of the parameters is revealed by the ecological factor and the interaction detector decides if a parameter can independently contribute to the fluctuation in the change in NPP51.Factor detectorIt is used to determine how much each natural factor contributes to the spatial distribution of NPP. The goal is to assess how each natural factor individually impacts the spatial distribution of NPP. The methodology involves several steps: first, spatial superposition and analysis of the NPP layer and natural factor layers; second, division of the natural factors into different spatial categories or classes; and finally, calculation of the mean differences of these natural factors. The significance test is then used to determine the relative importance of each natural factor. The F-test determines if there is a significant difference in the variances.$$\begin{aligned} F=\frac{\sigma ^2_{A,\, p}}{\sigma ^2_{A,\ r}} \end{aligned}$$
                    (9)
                where, \(\sigma ^2_{A,\, p}\) is the dispersion variance, and \(\sigma ^2_{A,\ r}\) is the stratified population dispersion variance. The geographical strata are defined as r and p is the sample units in each strata, while A represents the variable.$$\begin{aligned} B_{WG}=q=1-\frac{\sigma ^2_{A,\, r}}{\sigma ^2_{A,\, p}} \end{aligned}$$
                    (10)
                \(B_{WG}\) is the power of determinant of z to the NPP. As the q value (\(0< q < 1\)) increases, so does the influence of the influence of the factor.Interaction detectorThe detector explains the factor \(A'\) and \(A{''}\) on the NPP. The procedure involved the following steps: first, we computed the q values for \(A'\) and \(A{''}\), denoted as \(q(A')\) and \(q(A{''})\), respectively. The interaction between the two factors is calculated as \((q(A' \cap \, A{''}))\) to understand the type of interaction. In this study, we used the interactive detector to measure the coupling effect of topography and climate factors on NPP51,52. The criteria to segregate the values into interaction types is detailed in Table 7.Table 7 The conditions to realize the impact of pairwise combined effect on NPP is described. The effects of individual variables are non-linearly diminished by the interaction of two variables (\(NL\cdot Wn\)). The effects of individual variables are weakened by single-variable interactions (\(UV\cdot Wn\)). The effects of individual variables are enhanced by two-variable interactions (\(BV\cdot Enh\)). The impacts of variables operate independently of each other (IN). The effects of variables are amplified in a non-linear manner (\(NL\cdot Enh\)).Full size tableRisk detectorIt is employed to determine if there was a notable difference in the mean attribute between two subregions of each factor and to identify areas where NPP had either declined or improved. t-test53. The risk for the geographical zone r is defined as \(Z_r\). The t-test is carried out with number of samples p in the r zone as \(n_{r,p}\)$$\begin{aligned} t_{\overline{Z_{r=1}}-\overline{Z_{r=2}}} = \frac{\overline{Z_{r=1}}-\overline{Z_{r=2}}}{\left[ \frac{1}{d_{r=1,\, p}}\sigma ^2_{\overline{Z_{r=1}}}+\frac{1}{d_{r=2,\, p}}\sigma ^2_{\overline{Z_{r=2}}}\right] ^{1/2}} \end{aligned}$$
                    (11)
                degree of freedom$$\begin{aligned} df=\frac{\left[ \frac{1}{d_{r=1,p}}\sigma ^2_{\overline{Z_{r=1}}}+\frac{1}{d_{r=2,\, p}}\sigma ^2_{\overline{Z_{r=2}}}\right] }{\frac{1}{d_{r=1,\, p^{-1}}} \left[ \frac{1}{d_{r=2,\, p}}\sigma ^2_{\overline{Z_{r=1}}} \right] ^2 + \frac{1}{d_{r=2,\, p^{-1}}} \left[ \frac{1}{d_{r=2,\, p}}\sigma ^2_{\overline{Z_{r=2}}} \right] ^2} \end{aligned}$$
                    (12)
                null hypothesis \(H_0: \overline{Z_{r=1}}=\overline{Z_{r=2}}\)if \(\left| t_{\overline{Z_{r=1}}-\overline{Z_{r=2}}} \right| > t_{\alpha /2}\)Ecological detectorThe model aimed to assess if the impact of any two factors on the evolution of NPP varied significantly. The analysis determined whether \(A_1\) had a greater effect on the spatial distribution of NPP compared to \(A_2\), using the F statistic for measurement. The dispersion variance for \(A_1\) and \(A_2\) are defined as \(\sigma ^2_{A_1,\, r} = \frac{1}{d_{A_1,\, p}}\sum _{r=1}^{d_{A_1,\, r}}\sum _{p=1}^{d_{r,\, p}}\left( Z_{A_1, \,p} - \overline{Z_{A_1,\, p}}\right) ^2\) and \(\sigma ^2_{A_2,\, r} = \frac{1}{d_{A_2,\, p}}\sum _{r=1}^{d_{A_2,\, r}}\sum _{p=1}^{d_{r,\, p}}\left( Z_{A_2, \,p} - \overline{Z_{A_2,\, p}}\right) ^2\) respectively. The test is defined as$$\begin{aligned} F=\frac{d_{A_1,\, p}(d_{A_1,\, p}-1)\sigma ^2_{A_1,\, r}}{d_{A_2,\, p}(d_{A_2,\, p}-1)\sigma ^2_{A_2,\, r}} \end{aligned}$$
                    (13)
                Multiple linear regression (MLR)Analyzing the impact of multiple independent variables on one dependent variable is achieved through the MLR54,55. The regression assumes that the dependent variable is directly related to a linear combination of the explanatory variables. The regression model is formulated as:$$\begin{aligned} x=\beta _0+\beta _1y_1+\cdots +\beta _ny_n+\epsilon \end{aligned}$$
                    (14)
                where x is the dependent variable, and \(y_i\) is the independent variable. When all the explanatory variables are 0, \(\beta _0\) is the constant of the dependent variable. \(\beta _i\) is the coefficient of the explanatory variable and \(\epsilon\) is the error coefficient. The t value is the representation of the test statistics of the two-sided t-test. The likelihood of the result to have occurred by chance is inversely related to the t value.The validation of the MLR model fitness assumes that there is a low or nonexistent correlation between the explanatory variables. The data set is checked to fulfill the assumptions for MLR. Independent observations are made, the variance of residuals is constant throughout the linear model, and normal distribution is observed for the residual of the model. A nearly linear relationship is seen between the explanatory variables and NPP. The residual values are estimated very close to zero and the data is nearly equally distributed on both the positive and the negative side which reiterates the assumption of the data upholding heteroscedasticity. The Pearson correlation was used to test for multicollinearity, which indicated that LAI and FPAR produced a very high positive correlation (> 0.7) and hence theoretically it was not suitable to be used. So an alternate MLR model was derived by excluding the LAI and FPAR parameters. The resulting plot did not show any significant change. Also when comparing the \(R^2\) value, the model with all the parameters showed a high value of \(R^2\) which meant that the model was a better fit for the dataset. Also, the model with all the parameters had a smaller RMSE value. In conclusion, despite the independent parameters of LAI and FPAR having a high correlation with each other, they were utilized in the MLR since removing them did not have any benefit in the model performance. From the results obtained from \(R^2\), RMSE, Adjusted \(R^2\), MAE, Average RMSE across 10 folds, AIC value, BIC value it is deduced that despite the assumption not being completely satisfied, the model with all the parameters is the best-fitted model.
